content.user_title: Initialize Git Worktrees for Isolated Development
content.value_statement: Managing multiple branches and features in parallel is challenging. This skill creates isolated git worktrees automatically using conventional branch naming, enabling clean parallel development without stashing or switching branches.
actual_capabilities: Generate conventional branch names from task type and description
Create isolated git worktrees in .worktrees directory
Set up remote tracking branches automatically
Support 10 task types: feat, fix, hotfix, docs, refactor, test, chore, perf, ci, style
Apply naming rules: lowercase, hyphens, no special characters
Provide cleanup instructions after PR merge
limitations: Requires existing git repository with configured remote
User must manually navigate to created worktree directory
No automatic branch deletion after merge
Does not handle merge conflicts or rebasing

use_cases.title: Parallel feature development
use_cases.description: Work on multiple features simultaneously without stashing changes or switching branches repeatedly.

use_cases.title: Quick bug fix isolation
use_cases.description: Create an isolated workspace for production hotfixes without disturbing current development state.

use_cases.title: Documentation updates
use_cases.description: Maintain clean separation between code changes and documentation updates using dedicated branches.

best_practices: Use descriptive task descriptions that clearly indicate the work being done
Choose the appropriate task type (feat, fix, hotfix, etc.) for proper branch categorization
Clean up worktrees after merging PRs using the provided cleanup commands
anti_patterns: Using spaces or uppercase letters in branch descriptions breaks naming conventions
Creating worktrees without pushing to remote loses branch tracking benefits
Leaving unused worktrees accumulate in .worktrees directory over time

faq.question: What is a git worktree?
faq.answer: Git worktrees let you check out multiple branches simultaneously in separate directories without stashing changes.

faq.question: Where are worktrees created?
faq.answer: Worktrees are created in a .worktrees folder at your repository root for organized storage.

faq.question: Can I use this with any git hosting service?
faq.answer: Yes, it works with GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket, or any git remote that accepts standard git push operations.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: This skill only operates within your existing git repository. No external data access or network calls to third parties.

faq.question: What if the branch already exists?
faq.answer: The skill will report an error. Choose a more specific description or check if work is already in progress.

faq.question: How is this different from git checkout -b?
faq.answer: Git worktrees create isolated directories for parallel work, while checkout -b switches your current directory context.
